This is not just a song. It's a true work of art. From the very first note, it captures your attention and refuses to let go. The voice carries both fragility and strength, guiding us through a story that feels deeply intimate yet universally relatable. The single-take video? A cinematic masterpiece in itself, raw and unfiltered, where every movement of the camera feels intentional and alive. Listening to it feels like holding onto someone who exists halfway between reality and memory. Close, yet unreachable. Few songs manage to blend music and visual storytelling on this level. This is just haunting, beautiful and timeless. A masterpiece in every sense.

I like to think in money game 3 Ren isn't just talking about well the "money game" but I think it's also a cautionary tale about what a life with no love does to someone. We hear nothing about Jimmy's mother, so I'm gonna assume she wasn't in his life or Jimmy ignored her, also I wouldn't put his father past being abusive to her and trying to separate Jimmy and his mom. While Jimmy's father may have loved him it was definitely a "tough love" dynamic. So that's like no unconditional love from his parents. Jimmy's father lead him down a path devoid of love even in his school years, we here nothing about him dating other people, likely because either he was scared of what his father would think, he was too focused on his studies or his father forbid it. Even in later life Jimmy never found love, there's this whole part with the prostitute, so chances are he never even had a wife. Lastly we don't hear of any friends Jimmy had so there's not even that platonic love in his life. It's a well crafted tragedy and I love it!  Edit: one thing I thought about is maybe the success and pressure from his father made Jimmy see himself as above love. Yet also I think Jimmy hasn't lived a life without love more or so I think he lived a life with CONDITIONAL love from his father, which heavily messed him up, in his last moment he hears his own father say he's a shame which no man should ever say to a child. Yet Jimmy 100% loved his father I just think the conditional love messed him up. Or I'm distracting from the main reason, I dunno :)

I know Ren or anybody probably won't read this, but I'm 17. Been listening to Ren's music for a while, and thought I had truly understood it till recently. After being pushed out from my home town with my mother and 2 brothers, due to gentrification in a mostly black and Hispanic neighborhood. After we all had been celebrating the new Starbucks, McDonald's, the new family dollar, the newly fixed streets. Our home town looked good again just for them to turn around and start raising rent knowing most of the people they rented to were working class and on welfare just to feed their family's. We moved to Florida still can't afford a home, make too much to considered poor enough to help, make too little for any landlord to feel like we have the stability for them to rent to us. Having to watch my mother cry and struggle for money, my grandfather dying due to an avoidable infection after watching his nurses mistreat him first hand after helping himself myself for years. Being diagnosed with autism and going to therapy while my family wants me to get a job, but all these jobs are crying for experience I don't have due to age and won't even give me a second glance whether it be because the autism, inexperience, or race. It makes me feel sick cause I know none of this is fucking needed, it feels like I'm watching from the outside as wolves tear at each other bit by bit and leave the bones for the rest. I know it's unnecessary to write this in a YouTube comment section but listening to this trilogy in my playlist after a year of not hearing it made me cry and made me stop to think.  Cause I know I'm no better cause sometimes I feel like money would solve all our problems, but I know it wouldn't.

around the pavements of his city Five years old, and his daddy told him, listen here son, you've got to learn to be a man A man he works for what he wants Six years old, and he's reading, writing, top of the bunch And when he's seven, his progression made him student number one Eight years old and he's praised for unusual grades Nine, his parents pay for private school to nurture the flame 10, 11, 12, 13, he ascends and ascends, his daddy tells him, son, money is the means to all ends 14 solving complex mathematic equations, at 15, IQ 150, still elevating 16 he develops complex software code that detects weaknesses in cyber security protocol 17, and he sells his vision, keeping the share, not yet an adult But he's practically a millionaire 18, and his daddy tells him now you're a man the world don't give a damn about you So take all that you can 19, he turns a profit, stocks and shares, invest in product 20, double down deposits 21, his income rockets 22, he learns that truth is just this product 37, eyes glazed, disposition demonic 38, with a prostitute, a moment of passion Heating up the silver spoon and then chasing the dragon 39, getting reckless and hungry for power Daddy's In a society where profit is its highest value, there's no room for any other value. A doomed pyramid with cold material on top.  I am personally not against pursuing a wealthy life, as after the basic necessities for survival and a dignified life are accomodated, there should still be some material room left - for everyone - for investing in their own dreams, a certain freedom and room to make mistakes and try again before one becomes homeless and hopeless. I believe in a society with equal opportunities and where one has special talents and is sharing them with the world, should be able to create more quality and to help others (if that is within their own heart, too, but not all talented people have it, so I'm not here to blame anyone).  What's sad...is when material and spiritual are not in balance. When adults have managed reaching a certain age, solely focusing on their competitive goals, out of fear, never out of love.  But Love is more powerful than fear and it is more powerful than hate and it is more powerful than greed, it is more powerful than the illusory lack of it and Love will find its way to the coldest of hearts, one day and everything will be fixed as it will rightfully be Top Value on the top of a metaphorical pyramid. âœ¨ğŸ«¶âš¡

Incredibly talented & a wonderful storyteller. However, I'm going to point out that utopia shouldn't be a goal. It's not achievable, so one who seeks it will always be disappointed. As long as we live in an open society of free thinking people, one person's idea of utopia will  never align with someone else's. I know that this has probably been covered, or that I'll get a bunch of backlash for this opinion but please try and view this as a possibility and understand that I know the other more obvious views.   The dad isn't a bad or greedy person trying to instill in his son that he needs to make a lot of money. The entire time Jimmy misunderstands his father's words. Likely because men of older generations can be pretty bad about communicating what they actually mean. So let's break down possible boomer translation  Age 5 "listen here son, you've got to learn to be a man. A man he works for what he wants" This could be instilling a sense of responsibility and dedication to family. The traditional role of being a "man" is to be a strong provider and protector. He never says anything about money or material wants.  Age 9: parents pay for private school to give jimmy the best chance at having a good life that they can.  Age 18: "now you're a man, the world don't give a damn about you So take all that you can" Jimmy's dad could be trying to convey the harsh reality of life as an adult and trying to convey that you have to grasp onto the things that make you happy when you can because you may not get another opportunity. Again, nothing specifically mentioning money or material things.  Age 25: "listen here, son, while you're sitting in the palace That don't mean that you won"  I view this as Jimmy's dad seeing that greed has taken hold of him, and he's trying to convey that having all that money isn't going to make him happy in life.  Age 30: "you're losing the race You're just a servant to the king, not even in second place" I think this is again, Jimmy's dad trying to warn him that the path of greed is not going to make him happy in life. A servant to the king meaning, either a slave to money, or pointing out that he's just a cog in the political and economical corruption.  When looking at it this way, Jimmy's dad really wanted what was best for him and tried as well as he could to get him on the right path to a happy life. If Jimmy had just set aside his greed, then that's when his father would have been happy and approved of him. It's extremely sad that poor communication, especially from that generation, can cause such trauma to us.   Thanks for listening to my Ted talk.

To love the girl I love look like it's always my last night on earth or hers so when I am gone no one will have to wonder how I felt if I love them because I showed them everyday. Dear SIR Ren, thank you for deep emotions that you inflicted on me. Your lyrics and theyr's  visual representations goes trought my skin right to bones. It's painfull as it should be. But that pain wakes up many...
Here's a story... about 3 years ago, I lost my right leg... about a year after that, my boyfriend of 13 years died. 3 weeks later, I lost my other leg. Everything coming at me so fast, I left everything ive ever owned and went into a nursing home wearing my dead boyfriends favorite shirt and my purse.   I'm getting to the hopeful part. So, I was in there for 2Â½ years... TODAY... November 12, I got out and am in my new apartment. Im feeling hopeful and less suicidal.    I'm in constant physical pain, just had kidney stones and broke my hand.. but I'm still here  People tell me all the time how strong I am, they they couldn't go through what I did.... and I tell them BULLSHIT!, strength has nothing to do with it... you just have to adapt...  with me I had to find new ways to do things.. it's not strength, it's because you have no choice.  Okay, I'm getting there... you're going through a lot right now, and sometimes you get so overwhelmed you don't know where to start... One thing at a time. I know it sounds silly, but you will get through this and find your happiness and hope. I have new legs now, one is bionic.. very not religious.. but sometimes I feel things are getting better because I deserve it. So do you. You deserve to beat this. I understand the pain.. it can be all consuming,  or you can practice Mindfulness for chronic pain.  It sounds ridiculous,  but there are techniques where after a while, you're still in pain, but you feel it as a part of you, it becomes normal. I'm not describing it right.  Fuck, I'm wired. Sorry  Also geniuses and neurodivergents tend to find eachothet  I think it would be extremely cathartic for you to do a song about your pain... from your viewpoint and from others  You will see you are not alone. Meaning a high intellect needs simulati0n. Write a beautiful song about what it's like to be sick,

I watch the money game trilogy at least once a month. I know plenty of other young people are disgusted by late stage capitalism's demand for violence and oppression, but it's rare to have a productive and affirming chat about it. It's hauntingly lonely to think about so often when most people gave up caring before 20. Money Game parts 1 through 3 remind me that a cultural revolution is yet brewing, and I may live to see humans care for humans on a systemic level.

On a dark rain soaked evening Jimmy confronted the ghosts of his past the life driven by greed, ambition and a thirst for wealth that had rendered him a prisoner of his making. With a trembling hand on a 45 caliber  he whispered the echoes of his fatherâ€™s lessons the tragedy of a life devoted to a money game. As he pressed the trigger, a final desperate culmination of lessons unlearned, both from his father and the world he had navigated resonated in that last moment. It was a story of a boy named Jimmy who had once desired the world but ended with nothing but the absence of his own humanity.

I'm not going to repeat a load of already-made comments; we know this is a work of art. I'm just going to add a couple of observations on the video I've not seen made.  First, is it just serendipity that the globe stops spinning at the exact moment Ren answers the phone? With all the meticulous planning, I couldn't say.   Second, when he stands up and says, "This isn't entertainment...," we get a couple of lines that remind me, from the cadence, of Shakespeare.  I can't recall the play that it reminded me of, but, if I'm right, it just seems another example of all the references you get from a Ren video

"This world don't give a damn about you so take all that you can."... The hollow decades of life Jimmy lived is only possible if Jimmy's dad is right, because otherwise someone caring would step in at some point in the story, to save Jimmy from his fate, don't you think? Why do you only cry about his story when he kills himself, when the actual sad part is the decades of suffering he had to endure in his hateful reality? Could it be because you fear death? So it only momentarily seems like you guys are capable of empathy and care, when a literal survival instinct kicks in in you? I bet you thought Jimmy is evil or at least dumb, because he only cares about money. But assuming his dad is actually right and everything else in this world is just a soulless facade, what else is there to even go for? How exactly is it evil or dumb then? It's only sad, and it's true. From the very beginning, it's literally the story. Noone gave a fuck about Jimmy. Jimmy's dad was right! It's a story of a lot of people. We get perceived by the world as evil, but the world is the one evil to us. When the entire world is constantly hostile, you can either lose or fight it with hostility. There is no therapy to make someone like Jimmy help himself, there is no third option he could pick. Jimmy chose the latter and then he realized there is no point and changed his mind to the former.

I'm a few months late to this party, but I think people are overlooking a key detail of this story. When Ren pulls the trigger, all we hear is the "CLACK" because the gun isn't racked. In my mind, he could have added a gunshot in post production to drive the point home...but why didn't he?  Whether I'm looking too deep or not  I see it as Jimmy's .45 failing to fire, and failing to end his life. He sits there, soaking wet, still alive, realizing his suicide attempt failed because of such a tiny action. He has to sit there, suddenly faced with the choice to rack that slide.  An optimist might see this as him suddenly having a second chance, possibly even an epiphany. He could use that chance to turn things around and start using that wealth to fight the very same system he abused to rise to his position. He could finally take his finger off the trigger and use his immense power and wealth to fix what he did wrong.  Would he? I don't know. The story ended the moment that trigger was pulled. We have no idea if it goes any further. But if it does, I see that as an option.

She ended up with extreme skin cancer that transferred to being brain cancer that made her so ill that she died. If we are not experiencing it all first hand, there is something or a someone inbetween us and it. Either we are following teachers or scriptures, we are following just another feeling towards the same thing that we are experiencing ourselves right here in this now, in our slightly different but still same imperfect now. When learning any kind of passed down information no matter where on the spectrum of truth it is ranging, we are by doing so un-learning ourselves to put ourselves under & add on someone else's inner stance, which with time are going to make us, our inner being, into more of a copy than an actual self. Life is live, feel, learn and re-remember and the life we live is the teacher itself, where by living it we should be growing into living books of knowledge, if we actually live it for ourselves. We are both the teacher and the student, as we are both the observer and the one who project the whole moving picture that we see infront of us and dive into each new day when we open our eyes and the camera is again for us, rolling. We are all playing a lead-role in a meaningless story called life. Meaningless until we give it our  meaning & then we are acting as each others mirrors as well, reflecting all that greatness but also the inner work which we are taught to just brush under the carpet. So really, we should be grateful for all interaction with life as there is a teacher in absolutely everything. When breaking it down, all we truly have is our energy and together with our energy all we truly need in this life is good health, good morals and a fine-tuned instrument, as in us, to express ourselves properly with, in order to free our minds. let the caged bird fly! Follow no one who wishes followers but the one's who encourage you to live your life for you and to walk your own path. Only by doing so we'll truly know who we are and what we are truly here for. We have it all already & we need no middle-men in order to stay connected to ourselves as we are that creators energy...we are it. We are all born out of it and we're given a slightly different perspective to take in the experience with for a reason. So not to fall for false light. Saying that though, we can not escape what we are not first aware of. We are all god until it finds a way to poison the mind. ğŸ’œ

Okay, let's get deep in the subject for a minute. âš  Money is not the problem. Money is a misused good solution, that derives from the real root of all evil, the notion of property. Many ugly behaviors also derive from this notion, like racism, sexism, homophobia and all discriminations or oppressions, because they all look to set a group of us, the good, and a group of them, the bad, who can be abused and used to create wealth for those powerful enough to make those groups rules. There is a psychological logic to that, but the aim of the civilisation is exactly to avoid that by providing security to the entire group. So, we shall ban property, there is plenty and enough proof for it, but it ain't done for this notion is so well implanted in people's minds. The problem in our society, that is rich enough to feed, shelter, care, educate, have productive occupation and entertain the whole population, is that some of the most powerful people don't believe in civilisation any more, on two levels: they had to abuse or rob plenty of people to get to that position, and they allow privileges only to those who do the same. Super rich and super powerful are tolerated only because of the notion of property.  The second big issue in our civilization is the notion I call "mechanisism" for we think machines will solve all our problems, and we forget that humans are still better at it. Okay, it's true that industry and technical science have given a great boost to humanity lately, but it's not the one and all. In the meantime, we didn't make any progress in human sciences, like sociology, psychology nor politics. We have the world in the palm of our hand but we still think like 200 years ago. Worse, we think and act more and more with passion and envy rather than with reason and wisdom. And lying became a sport.  Back to Ren's artwork; the emphasis for my these is repeated twice: "Mine, mine, give me". Also, a great solution is highlighted in the shadows of the story and more clearly in the conclusion: Education is key. We need to teach all youth (even the old ones) to care, to respect, to share... Peace & Love, y'all!

In today's tumultuous world, where political agendas seem to serve only the interests of a select few, your presence is a beacon of hope and unity. Amidst the chaos, your commitment to bridging divides and upholding strong ethical values shines through, a rare trait in the current political landscape.  From my perspective, gleaned from observing your actions and those of other voices like Russel Brand, it's become evident that both ends of the political spectrum harbor ideas essential for fostering a harmonious and prosperous society. The key lies in finding common ground and allowing practicality and reason to guide us forward. Formerly entrenched in left-leaning beliefs, I've come to recognize, with the guidance of individuals like yourself, the importance of embracing a collective vision that prioritizes the well-being of the majority over the interests of a privileged few.  Thank you for championing rationality and compassion in a world increasingly defined by division. Your influence has been instrumental in guiding me towards enlightenment and understanding.  And on a lighter note, your musical talents never fail to astound! Apologies for veering into the political realm, but I genuinely believe that the pervasive influence of vested interests has fractured our society. Individuals like you, however, are instrumental in shedding light on the importance of common-sense solutions. Thank you for your unwavering dedication to the greater good.

me senti vendo hamilton
A species that has struggled and clawed to survive will always find a way to do so. You HAVE to eliminate and reduce the ways in which one can achieve this aim that hurt others.  We should not expect people to be good, to make good decisions. We shouldn't give them a choice, because when you are so limited by whatever information is given to you through culture, finances, geography, your choices are limited.  You have to design a system that doesn't expect good behavior, but simply makes it default. Being a good person isn't just a standard, it is normalcy. We have badly messed up our code of society when we leave room for people to profit and win the survival game by doing things that reduce the time and quality of others survival. Remove the incentive. Remove the reward, no matter how it is earned and you won't see that behavior.  We all agree that human life has value, in theory, not in practice. We're still too stuck trying to survive because others for whatever reason or another have taken paths in which their aim of survival reduces the chances of ours. We make things dog eat dog with the system we have. We have to change the system itself, the things we approve of and why and remove rewards for abhorrent behavior, no matter what the drive for doing it is, survival or greed, because greed is just future fear over survival that is pre-emptive. I take more now in case I need it later, even if I don't need it now, I might. Greedy people are scared. Remove fear and you find that we're a pretty docile species. How do I know this? We're all fucking terrified, yet music like this is made. Messages like this are understood and heard. We're not in fact falling apart like we think we are because people have empathy. We understand our personal survival is dependent on those around us and no one does anything alone. Thinking that they do inflates ego and distorts reality that everything that exists doesn't exist by itself. Everything interplays off of other things to make something new. The horrors our reality has still have bright moments, which proves to me our species isn't doomed. It's just not fun to realize how much further we all need to go, how much we have to work on and how disillusioned we've been. All trying to find the answer and struggling to find the cause of the disease so that we can fix it.

I`m new to Ren for which I apologize and I have been catching up watching countless videos. In the last 2 years, I`ve lost 4 close family members, arranged 3 funerals and my mental health is rock bottom, I haven`t put a gun to my head but a noose around my neck - bottled it. Lyrics Let me tell you a story about a boy named Jimmy One years old and his first words were mine, mine gimme Two years old, he was walking, three years old, walking quickly Four years old, he was running around the pavements of his city Five years old, and his daddy told him, listen here son, you've got to learn to be a man A man he works for what he wants Six years old, and he's reading, writing, top of the bunch And when he's seven, his progression made him student number one Eight years old and he's praised for unusual grades Nine, his parents pay for private school to nurture the flame 10, 11, 12, 13, he ascends and ascends, his daddy tells him, son, money is the means to all ends 14 solving complex mathematic equations, at 15, IQ 150, still elevating 16 he develops complex software code that detects weaknesses in cyber security protocol 17, and he sells his vision, keeping the share, not yet an adult But he's practically a millionaire 18, and his daddy tells him now you're a man the world don't give a damn about you So take all that you can 19, he turns a profit, stocks and shares, invest in product 20, double down deposits 21, his income rockets 22, he learns that truth is just an obstacle to wealth If you manipulate the data, then the lie will sell itself 23, a life of luxury Crystal and cocaine 24, he makes the Forbes list, they're applauding his name 25, and his daddy told him, listen here, son, while you're sitting in the palace That don't mean that you won 26, his business shifts, he switches business to arms He's 27, dealing nuclear shells in Iran 28, inside the Senate, money bought him a seat He's 29, role of counsel in the president suite And now he's 30, his daddy says, you're losing the race You're just a servant to the king, not even in second place 31, a big maneuver for his daddy's approval Moving imports over borders from the exports out of Cuba 32, moving grams, growing kilo to tons He's 33, filling warehouses with powder and guns 34, turf war with nobody to stop it, blind eye from the Po po inside of his pocket 35, he gets a call, I'm sorry, son, but it's your father, had a heart attack I'm sorry, he's gone, 36, getting pissed off abusing this product 37, eyes glazed, disposition demonic 38, with a prostitute, a moment of passion Heating up the silver spoon and then chasing the dragon 39, getting reckless and hungry for power Daddy's words still driving him to kill him and devour He makes a move against the cartel, but the strategy's flawed They retaliate and leave him in the hospital ward A bullet buried in his vertebra, and one in his leg The doctor sighs and says, I don't think you'll be walking again, fuck Let me tell you a story about a boy named Jimmy He was 40 and he cursed the words mine, mine gimme 41, he wasn't walking, 42, not walking quickly, 43 Never running round the pavements of his city 44 inside a palace with a mountain of gold But those riches turn to rubble when perspective evolves Weighing heavy on his conscience is the value of gold, Lamborghini for a life Trading money for souls, Jimmy followed the code inside the land of the free Put your hand inside the cookie jar, take more than you need And his example is exaggerated versions of me, and it's a version of him And it's a version of she, and it's a version of you There's no escaping the blame, the way we live, it's parasitic Fuck the money and fame, cut the music This isn't entertainment, this is real life, the way we live is lunacy, community it declines We're hyperpolarized, we're always fighting and we divide Truth is less important than the money that we designed? Money's an invention, politics from our invention, they all come from people's ideas Did I mention, border's an invention Law and order fuels the tension that leads to people killing each other My solution? Everything is subject to change We could build utopias if individuals were taught to use their brains But if we teach kids in schools to always be sheep and put themselves before the herd If there's more money for meat Then there's no future I see where the humans survive We're parasites inside the Petri dish, with cannibal mines Mold will grow upon the surface, then consumes 'til it dies And our fate could be the same without this story to the wise 45, Jimmy comes home out of the rain, soaking wet upon a wheelchair Drinking again, he has everything he wants, he has fortune and fame Such a fortunate fool with an unfortunate fate with a 45 caliber aimed at his brain 45, a fitting number because his age is the same Here's the words of his father, it's such a damn shame Then he presses on the trigger of a money game

I have never been accustomed to admiring artists or famous people because most of the time i can not relate deeply to that person or the messages they portray or publicize. Ren has now changed this for me. I am i awe of his talent, authenticity and strength! For someone who has had trouble with mental health herself, due to having trouble understanding how our society is so sick as a human race and wishing i could fix it, but feel powerless, listening to your music makes me feel like I'm not alone or going crazy. I HATE how money is a priority, how certain people are trying to divide us all when at the end of the day no matter what race, colour etc we are, we are all human! We all have the same basic needs which is physiological, safety, love, belonging, esteem and self-actualization! Nothing more, nothing less! That feeling we are all mice running on a constant wheel to no where due to lack of compassion, understanding, empathy, community and a force of evil/toxicity trying to tear us down is heartbreaking for me. Realizing we are all so gifted in our unique way and have so much more to offer than fame, wealth, materialistic items and "perfection" is something i hope for on a daily basis for our next generation. As well as for the kindness of humanity to survive. Sending much love and hope to everyone! I obviously don't know Ren personally but i feel so proud of him! The health problems and mental health issues he has had to endure i don't wish on anyone! But to still keep fighting and never give up and to still be so committed to pursing his purpose and spreading light on whats wrong with the world, but at the same time sending a message on what should be the true focus as human beings.... in my eyes..... it's the hope, change and strength we all need to hear and see, so our light within us doesn't diminish and makes us come back to realization of what really matters. At times it can be hard when we are constantly programmed to think otherwise! Thank you Ren!

Just found this man's channel and I can honestly say I love it, love what you sing and how you sing. Geat music brother
This reminds me of my time in the theater as an assistant director. Get the preparations, samples, equipment, repair. Last minute disasters. Then the excitement of the dress rehearsal. Excitement and concentration. Ren must have felt exactly like I did on opening day. Just one chance. In your case, the rain was doomed to a one-take. And then the curtain. And even though it was over, nobody knew what to do with themselves. When Ren said he didn't know whether to cry- I felt that way. We were of no use for days. Premiere hole. When the play stopped playing, we would meet up and talk about how we were doing so we wouldn't fall into depression. We felt so lonely without the theater family. What I found particularly great about Ren's set: There was no evaluation afterwards. We always had to endure that the day after the premiere. Everyone knew what didn't go so well or what they could have done better. Why pick on it. Ren just thanked everyone and thats it. That felt good. He also thought about the little boy who shouldn't have to wear a sack over his head for hours. Wonderful. So focused. I always wondered: how does he remember every comment he gets along the way? I had to write everything down. Unbelievable, this focus! And the politeness on set. Simply great. I would work with a team like that again in a heartbeat.

You know, as with all great art, there's so many meanings you can pull from this song, but I don't see anyone talking about this one: This whole thing could've been avoided with five words: I'm proud of you, son.  The underlying theme of Jimmy constantly chasing his fathers approval, and it constantly leading him down worse and worse paths as the father is never satisfied, even while Jimmy's on top of the world. Until one day, even the merest hope of that approval is snatched away forever, leading him down a depressive spiral. After all, what was it all for? And the biggest tragedy? Jimmy himself probably never would even realize that's all it was.   Love your parents, make them proud, but more importantly, make yourselves proud, ladies and gentlemen. Because one day, your parents will be gone, and you'll still have to live with yourself.

One of the things I've always thought separates real pieces of (media) art from the rest: a strong sense of the flow of energy of a peice. Meaning knowing when to pause, when to surprise, when to repeat or change tone... it's *all* in the texture of that flow. And this thing has that awareness x100. It's not just lyrically, musically and in terms of the video brilliant, it's artistically tasteful.

Hey new sub but huge fan here.. Really havent bought an album since I was 14(saying this as a 90s girl). I'm saving up to buy all of yours. Thank you for doing what you do. It IS connecting. I've had cancer and severe autoimmune for my best years... and am still struggling with that and god and the why of the people I've lost over time.. let alone being enraged by the way the world is and how it affects me and my loved ones daily.. and how we may all be a part of it but it seems impossible to fix. You will never know how many people you help by just resounding like this in this way. It feels less lonely. No pressure moving forward but i know so much of the world is watching. Just keep being you and stop giving when you need to. Don't let others needs override what you need. I have a theory that's what good artists suffer from the most. The want to provide/preform/give and with too wide of an audience and too much care for said audience that you can easily get torn apart. In the beginning of the video, Ren (Jimmy) loosens the noose from the â€œmoney bagâ€ around his head. Brilliant :)
In 1948, Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery" appeared in The New Yorker. At first, it lures you into thinking that it's the story of humble farmers and their families living in small-town America. But by the end, you realize that this rural community where everyone knows each other on a first-name basis is not at all what you were expecting. I was in middle school when I first read it and during a class discussion, I distinctly remember another student commenting that while the protagonist accepted the system, she didn't accept what the system was doing to her. I feel like Ren's message is similar but with added emphasis that "We're all part of this old money game." Jackson's story portrayed a game of sorts and is titled with a word that has a strong association with money. Unlike Jackson, though, I feel Ren is saying we have the choice not to play a game that gives immense power to a select few.  Ren is absolutely brilliant.
Authentic...

Pretty intense....Cheers bo!
I agree with the message to a point but while many of the things we hold as concepts, are in fact concepts everyone agrees to as a society, they are just tools. They are not designed to inhibit growth to take from the "cookie jar" but to bake cookies so more can have some and in return for the service gain something to which they can continue to bake more cookies. Can tools be abused? Absolutely! That doesn't make the tools bad, it makes the abuser of the tools bad. There is such a thing as a bad person, yeah sometimes they were raised in a bad environment but that isn't what makes them bad, what makes a person good or bad is what they do with what they are given and in a free society not one person can stop you from becoming successful but yourself. In controlled, authoritarian, socialist societies, you are told what you are allowed to achieve, what you can create and how much.

I am not sure if I ever commented on a YouTube video before, but like many others, I was struck by the craft in this short film and had to stop to applaud it. Unlike Ren I do not have the ability to find words to describe what I feel and string it into sentences that are so powerful, honest and meaningful at the same time. Stories shape humanity so here I am commenting to feed the algorithm that I despise so much living in a world that is upside down. Perhaps what makes Ren's art stand out so much is that it is clearly driven by a message encapsulated by beautiful lyrics and music. In this cacophony of empty songs and videos omnipresent on the internet, it is a rarity. Dark and beautiful. If I were in a theatre that would be a standing ovation from me.

To put it very simple: Jimmy was born greedy His father fueled his greed When his father died, Jimmy lost control and his hunger for power became starvation influenced by substance use Jimmy overcalculated and got shot, becoming paralysed in the legs Then he realises he lost one of the thing that he enjoyed, walking and running (first verses versus verses after he got shot) He then realises money/physical wealth has no value and what matters are life experiences (Lamborghini for a life, trading money for souls)  This makes him realise he has no life, which puts him in depression and makes him pull the trigger (of the money game, which revealed itself as his life) [my interpretation]   To this there are also more things to consider: -"Jimmy's life is an exaggerated version of (all of us)" , showing we are all greedy at some point (else the world would be an utopia "We could build utopias if individuals were taught to use their brains" meaning it would be paradise on earth and our greed comes from our stupidity (drugs and our tendency to oversatisfy ourselves just because we can)   -interestingy, his mother is never spoken of, and this could be developed in future Ren's songs, or his father could have been just the rappresentation of the rational money game (that died from spontaneous drug usage degenerating into the cartel's attack, and so he always was an inner voice of his, but this is just a theory and interpretation)

Probably the best i've heard since Hi Ren.   Ren, you are a genius, and i really fucking mean it. This isnt just a good song, its an incredible song, and incredible performance, and an incredible delivery. What amazes me the most and gives me to think that you are one of the greatest artist since the turn of the century and a genius, it is not the your knowledge about music, it is the fact that you dont give a crap about it, break every scheme and still triumph like no one did.   Its crystal clear that you know how the music industry works, what formulas, melodies work the best, the "formula" to success. Yet, you dont give a damn about it, you morph it into your own creation, your own signature.   On 5:55, the melody you use works perfectly, its amazing, its so touching, nostalgic and sad, and instead of squeeze out everything you can, you just stopped. You could easily have let the melody go on and on till the end, and armonically it would sound amazing, leaving us with a fullfillment sensation. But no, thats not Ren. You go out to stop it, even if it breaks the melody and the armony, you do it anyway because there's a message you want to convey, theres a mark, a signature, you want to leave, the "Ren signature". And even though you broke the armony several times, even though you left us with a void sensation cause the melody stops, you still succeded. Cause thats Ren, even against all odds, even though you didnt have a discographic on your back, or unlimited budget, you rose up to number 2 and probably number 1 in the charts, and to be able to achieve all of this, it is what i would call someone a genius. And you truly are.    Apart from my own analysis of the song and how it succeded even when theoretically shouldnt, I gotta say, there hasnt been a single song I disliked since I listened to Hi Ren, not even one.   Most people got their one hit and then dont reach the expectations or just crumble after their one hit. But you? Yes, Hi Ren was the masterpiece that got you on the spotlight, but every song, before and after Hi Ren has been at least equally or close to the quality of your "one hit". Congrats, Ren, you deserve it all. Much love and support from Argentina <3

I wanted to take a moment to express my deep appreciation for your incredible talent and the profound impact your work has had on me. As someone with a rich history of experiencing various artists and music styles, often referred to as "boomer music," I can confidently say that your artistry is the most interesting, exciting, and versatile I have come across in decades.  I have immersed myself in your videos, reactions, and interviews, and I am truly in awe. Your ability to inspire, give hope, and make us reflect on what truly matters is unparalleled. Finally, we have an artist who embodies empathy, positivity, and the power to unite people from all walks of life. You have become a beacon of light in a world that sometimes feels uncertain.  Your music has become a source of comfort, a reminder of the beauty and resilience of the human spirit. It speaks to the core of our shared humanity and encourages us to embrace what is important in life. Your ability to connect with your audience on such a deep level is truly remarkable.  I believe in the power of humanity, and you, dear Ren, personify this belief. Through your work, you have become an inspiration for countless individuals, myself included. You have become a role model, someone we look up to and admire for your unwavering dedication to spreading positivity and fostering understanding.  I want to express my heartfelt gratitude for being the artist that defines this generation. Thank you for using your platform to uplift, encourage, and remind us of the goodness that exists within each and every one of us. Your art has touched my soul and has reminded me of the profound impact music can have on our lives.

Jimmy He was 40, and he cursed the words "Mine, mine, gimme" 41, he wasnâ€™t walking, 42, not walking quickly 43, never running 'round the pavements of his city 44 inside a palace with a mountain I am so enamored by the art emerging from  Ren and Samuel. It's thought-provoking and inspiring. As an aspiring artist who sold out over 15 years ago many of the topics are incredibly easy to relate to, including the unique perspective of someone who spends their lives living on the periphery of society - a great place to be to get a real view of the world and its machinations. While similar thematically to Handlebars by Flobots, this piece does a much better service by aiming the measage directly at the culprits - all of us. Consumerism and capitalism drive a very high percentage of people. Hell, look at all of the parasitic/arguably somewhat symbiotic nature of the Youtube reaction community as an example. Art being a commodity to pander. That said, what are the tangible steps out of this mess? Pointing out a societal disfunction is one thing, the path out is a much more labourious road. We are all monkeys in shoes; our enlightened sides always at war with our basic primal instincts. Figuring out how those two sides of the same coin (loosely quoting Ren) can work together to our benefit is the real trick. You can rightfully call me a cynic, but i fear that such a feat is beyond the capabilities of our current world.
THE TRILOGY IS COMPLETE YES
YOU NEVER DISAPPOINT!

My first time watching this one. Haven't gotten all the way thru yet. I've restarted it about 5 times now. The one thing I have realized, without a doubt @renmakesmusic, is that you are a certifiable genius. This journey you are taking us on, especially the money game, is a true work of art. But it's not just that; it's how you've released your tracks and how they have been found by others. Your artistry and what you have done is beyond incredible. I would say you are the first person to put on a global treasure hunt/play/psychological experience ever. More so, you did it with meaningful messages and real life experiences. You have written this over years and are letting us episodically see your play. you wrote us an incredible story, world, and history, that is being played out thru your music, videos, artistry, passion, pain, loss, triumph, realization, understanding, and growth The way you work your songs into one another is almost as if its lore. From violet, screech and Jenny to their constant references or nick names relating to your past and life, to your incredibly raw, and honestly humbling songs and references to your friend Joe. Your style of writing mixed with your overwhelming life experience and your wealth of musical knowledge has led you to something that is rarely seen. Remember thru all of this that you need to be healthy to continue this and that is most important. Never let anyone put expectations on you as this goes on. Not your fans, not venue's, not labels, no one. Hi Ren, I've been reflecting on the current state of the music industry and discussing it with some folks, especially in the context of your latest production. The sad reality is that nowadays, people with superficial understanding or even no real grasp of music are dictating the trends. They decide what's "in" and what's not, often sidelining the true essence of music in favor of showy visuals and repetitive lyrics.  But amidst this noise, you emerge as a beacon of genuine artistry and talent. Your recent work is a testament to the fact that true talent doesn't need exorbitant budgets to resonate and leave an impact. It brought to mind the depth and emotionality of "Freckled Angels". It's evident that all the physical and psychological challenges you've faced have shaped you, perhaps even driving you to create the profound music you do now. Like freckled angels who have seen the depths of life, you've risen, stronger and more capable, touching countless souls with your art.  You're not only showcasing your impeccable skills but also setting an example and paving a path for many budding artists. It's an inspiration, a reminder that genuine passion and dedication can indeed defy the norms set by those who might not truly "get" music.  Huge congratulations on this masterpiece, and thank you for reminding us all what real music feels like in an era often clouded by shallow trends. And don't forget to have fun. Not every piece has to be like this one ğŸ™‚

All the nice cinematography aside, the video complains that "Truth is less important than the money that we design."  So truth is important?  And we should follow the truth?   So what is Ren's "solution"?  He wants to eliminate money, politics, borders, and law and order.   He wants us to "use our brain" to achieve "utopia" because "everything is subject to change."  This all sounds reminiscent of enlightenment philosophy (God is dead),  Evolutionism, Marxism, and Communism.  Which are the very philosophies and political systems that literally led to the death, in the 20th century alone, of millions of people---mostly committed by governments against their own people.  Ren has identified part of the problem but he has no solution other than more of the same.  It almost sounds like he is primed for the coming of the New World Order and it's one world government.

Ren is unlike any other artist, this is incredible.
A musical analysis of Money Game 1-3 by Ren  So, Money Game are three songs made by the British singer  Ren. They talk about the game that is capitalism and how eventually we all lose to it, no matter how smart you are, you always end up with your finger in the trigger of the Money Game.   The first one, the critique:  https://youtu.be/0ivQwwgW4OY?feature=shared  Talks mostly about how bad the game is, how this twisted and evil game we play turns everyone into a monster that refuses to turn the mirror to ourselves, always pointing the blame and never stopping to realize that by pointing the blame, you already are playing the game.  Then, we move onto the second one, the guide: https://youtu.be/YonS9_QJbp8?feature=shared  This one starts criticizing the game but quickly jokes about it and instead, starts to explain how to play this game, the most effective tactic avaliable and what you should expect to happen, but certainly, no one would play the game like that. Right?  Third one, The Warning:  https://youtu.be/nyWbun_PbTc?feature=shared  This one, this one is rather sad. We finally get to see what happens when someone follows the guide, we see the wicked truth of this world we live in. This song is a warning to all of us, it's basically a way to say "follow the guide and you might end up like little jimmy", but why? Jimmy did everything right, he sold more than seashells, ran for president, swallowed his morals. But even then, he lost, he didn't step up to the stage, the world still wasn't his. It's as if the game was rigged from the start. I believe all three songs are connected somehow, each one complementing the last one until we get to this one. Someone that didn't know the game but entered it anyway, isn't that what happens to all of us? We are put into this unwillingly and forced to play, forced to dance to this horrible tune that none of us really know the rules for, yet we manage to just barely make it out alive. The harder we resist, the closer we are to break, change will come, that's the only constant in life other than death and taxes. So be careful out there,be careful when playing this old money game, because when you realize you're playing it your finger will already be on the trigger of a   Money Game

Fellow Lymie here - haven't commented previously because I consistently end up speechless from your astonishing combination of insane talent, heart, intelligence, creativity, spot-on insights and compassion that are so rightfully bringing you much deserved acclaim.  It's truly hard to articulate the impact your visionary music and messages are having on so many people.  I so hope that the treatment in Canada is successful and not too grueling, and you are able to enjoy the next chapter of your rising star journey while continuing to inspire and unite so many people who needed you to show up and allow them to feel seen and understood.  And this is not limited to those struggling with chronic illness and/or mental health challenges.  The world needs you on so many levels.  You're truly magic, Ren - thank you for delivering such beautiful gifts in spite of what has had to be a colossal and sometimes dauntingly exhausting effort through years of what I know first hand is often a living hell that only those who have been through it can appreciate.  I'd love to swap stories of what has been most effective for me, but everyone is different in what our immune systems respond to, and I hope you're receiving the best of the best there is to offer to bring you through the gauntlet.  You're a reminder of how much brilliance gets locked up by cruel, relentless and frequently misunderstood chronic illness and you are shining a brilliant and much needed light on the world. <3

Getting a little tired of these preachy theatrical acts, people using drama to sell product to angsty teens, a bit like American Idol (everyone has a sob story, mostly imagined or stolen). Nice performance though, good from a commercial point of view. Artistically: talented, but too formulaic and derivative for my taste. It's inauthentic, staged, manipulative, simplistic, pretentious, designed for effect. Not musically or intellectually satisfying, too desperate for fame, seems to me. Maybe later, when he's not focused on gaining an audience and pretending to be someone/something.  Sorry for being so negative, the performance just comes across as grandiose and pretentious, and the mix with rap/activism/storytelling seems to serve as an excuse to overlook deficiencies. He's definitely talented though, so maybe later.

Amazing work
It is as if Ren, and Sam combined into a two-headed auteur, have single-handedly begun the unwinding of neo-liberalism, the ideology ushered in by way of Thatcher and Reagan, that fifty year counter-revolution against the New Deal and the British post WW2 Welfare State.   Enter the ideology of individualism, stage right, where greed is now just an invisible hand, stroking a now-sanctified marketplace, a rolling back of gains birthed in the bloody cauldrons of the union movement. Where once our grandparents empowered themsleves as check on the Dickensian mindset,,we now had, instead, as the sun set on the 1970's, the banishment of Britian's famed Keynes, and any idea that the collective will could guide economic production toward the collective.   All this, and many other forces from the blowback of colonialism to decades of foreign coups on behalf of first national, then trans-national, corporations, to the OPEC embargo, all combined to birth the waters into which we all now must swim.  These are the same waters that drowned, erased, phrases like "public good" in the flood pains and peats of history.  Those two leaders broke the backs of miners and public unions while simultaneously selling us on "Greed is Good." At the dawn of the 1980s,  we had all now drank the collective Kool-Aid of individualism. Generations were born into a world where the highest aim of public office became private gain.   Chasing the sugar-high of privatization, directing public funds and shaping public policy to subsidize the profits of corporations, we allowed our leaders, acting on behalf of international finance, the military industrial complex and Big Oil  (Big Ag, Big Pharm, Big etc..) to shape the headwaters of the river in which we all now must swim, the modern, neoliberal corporate welfare state. ,  These are the waters where we've internalized as immutable truth, the concept that redistributing wealth upward is "economic stimulus," where the  myth of meritocracy is dangled in front of every  ambitious child, and where  competiton is fetishized. Debt, desperation, and austerity for the many are seen, not just as fuel government provides to drive down wages, but as much needed aid to Finance and Real Estate interests.   That same debt, that same desperation, in the internalized ideology we all accept as truth, why that's character-building, that's market-driven motivation for children and young adults, entire families and countless congregations, character-building to extract blood as tax from even medical care, a tax to fill the money bag,  tribute to the princes and dukes of private equity, purveyors and chief beneficiaries of this, The money game.   Ren and Sam are tryimg to drive us hack from the brink, so  we can re-invent the wheel of collective will, modernize it, liberate technology from the oligarchs, monopolists and war profiteers, channel it instead into helping us solve all the problems that "greed is good" has wrought and fossil fuels have poisoned.   Well, thats my take on MG3, for whatever fuck its worth

JUST DROPPED A FIRE REACTION TO THIS! SHOUTOUT TO REN FOR DROPPING THE FIRE CONTENT.
Ren, I really love your music and the messages you put out through your music. You are probably a really great guy. However, did I see the price for your Sick Boi album is $95 USD? Really? I'm disabled and live on benefits. Where in the world would I get that kind of money to purchase that album because I really really want it. I guess I can sacrifice a week of groceries. Or maybe I can forgo one of the meds that keep me alive this month. ğŸ˜¢ I'm so saddened and disappointed by the cost of the album. It's like part of the money game, isn't it? I can not participate in the money game. My disabilities make that happening very unprobable. I have Schizophrenia and recently discovered I've got these crazy white matter lesions scattered all through my left frontal lobe, causing many things but mostly dementia and I'm losing the use of my arms and legs. You who can participate in the money game, well cheers to you. I do realize how much time, effort, money, and genius went into your album. I'm sure it's worth more than what you're charging for it. Just know that it's cost cuts off people like me from enjoying your album and from contributing to your cause. No, I'm not asking for a handout. I've never asked for help from anyone. I've never used welfare or foodstamps. Housing assistance. Despite the Doctors telling my parents that I'd never be able to work or live on my own, I defied them. I held down two full careers for 20 years before I finally had to apply for disability. That wasn't taking a hand out. I paid into social security the entire time I worked. That money is my money. My savings to use.  I also raised two children. Put them through college. They are now very successful playing in the money game. Unfortunately Neither one of my kids listened to my teaching lectures that money means nothing. It's all about taking care of each other as human beings. They went to the dark side with their father. A rich corporate man. President of his department, sales. The kids now in their late 30's still think they aren't working hard enough because they don't have a billion dollars in savings. Come on. My daughter just bought my granddaughter a brand new Toyota SUV just as a gift. No special occasion. I'm just saying how it is. I don't want a free album. I don't have credit cards to charge it on. I can't pay the money back if I borrowed, so I chose not to get credit cards or loans. Do you offer a low interest payment plan with a flexible time frame for payments? I refuse to ask my kids for anything.
I do not need to point out to other Ren fans how beautiful and poignant this cautionary tale is. I just want to make my opinion known to the algorithm. Some people point to any one of several political figures this reminds them of. However, when I hear the line, 'If you manipulate the data, then the lie will sell itself,' it makes me think of Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos: fantastic job, Ren and all those involved with the creation of this masterpiece.  Bravo!

Liking all the comments here to PUMP this up!!
So heres my interpretation. Jimmy isn't dead. I might be looking too much at the fact both Hi Ren and Money Game Pt 3 are exactly 9 mins 20 secs. It's a little parallel I see to the idea this is all in Jimmy's mind. Hi Ren was a battle of the conscience and so is this. I see this song ending in 2 ways:  - Jimmy is dead. The story was all about his reality with no metaphor. I'm kinda not on board with this version.   - Jimmy isn't dead. Money Game Pt 1 had the line "Point the mirror at ourselves". The whole song is Jimmy's inner narrator reflecting back on his life. This starts with him removing the bag from his head to look at his reflection in the mirror. He is remembering how he got to where he is at the moment this song is happening.  In the process of revisiting these key moments in his life he is becoming more conscious to the idea that his life has not been in his own control. He's been a slave to the money game as much as anyone. So this hangar with all these memories he is walking through is the inside of his brain. This is him coming to the realisation that this is a person he doesn't want to be anymore. So when it comes to pulling the trigger on that gun, he isn't pulling it in the physical world. He's pulling the trigger on this old version of him. It's his moment of awakening to end that life and become a new and better person. A person who doesn't allow his life to be dictated by all of these sins he's been living up to that point.  It could even be that Jimmy didn't live this life at all. It could be that he is still young and this is all a point of making a decision in his life. The whole story could be him weighing up what path he wants to take in life. When he pulls the trigger, that is him making the decision that he doesn't feel that particular journey is worth it based on the anxious thoughts of destruction that he sees in his possible future on that path. So he's killing off that version of himself but not actually killing his real self. Whether he makes the right choice is up to the listener to decide at the end.

Similar to the way the opening verse and the verse where it speaks about Jimmy's first words and walking...The entire money game trilogy comes full circle in this song. "Rain, rain, rain, rain...A storm it comes our way. And those who rise through distorted lies, poison in their veins," The chorus from the original Money Game 1 and 2...It comes full circle with the ending of the story where Jimmy comes in soaking wet from being in the rain. And he has his finger on the trigger of a money game, but this time, the gun is aimed at himself, not at the others that he wanted to profit off. Money does not equal happiness. You can only find that from within yourself through love, patience, and respect for yourself and others. I think it's pretty clear that this is the message here. Chasing wealth and fame over everything and everyone will not only NOT bring you joy, it will destroy you. It will eat you from the inside out. Like mold growing on the surface of a petri dish, people chasing wealth will consume, consume, consume, but eventually they will die with a broken heart and a rotten soul.  Ren...you are an inspiration and an incredibly talented, intelligent and gifted artist. Keep killing it!

so the thing that goes deeper than politics and party is ideology and dogma. many countries have some version of a left and a right wing and what they distill down to in their essence is utilitarianism vs individualism. I've studied and thought a lot about the concepts Ren talks about this song and I believe solution only comes from a broad and widely adopted shift in ideology towards a specific mix of both and they are this: when it comes to matters of money and power and well being we must be utilitarian. when it comes to matters of personal freedom we must lean towards individualism. I like this video but I felt like it did the easy job which is tell a story of a flaw in capitalism, however it missed on any type of call to action. so I thought id add my own. try looking at matters of money and power through a utilitarian worldview and see what happens.
Bro, just keep making music that resignates with people. Dont sell your soul. Its Gods will. This world needs you.

Though I am retired and 100% disabled I still work a full time job assisting Veterans in healthcare and drug addiction. The conversation we all need to have is what then? There will always be groups of people fighting for power, religion and money, there will always be evil, those that believe â€œconvert, kill or enslaveâ€ I donâ€™t trust a damn person in government but if we did away with borders and built utopias, got rid of money and just helped each other in everyday life then how do we manage the people that form to do evil, want their own land, just enjoy hurting people or claiming someone else hurt them to punish a person they didnâ€™t like? I always hear â€œdo away with government and bordersâ€ but without some structure to maintain a type of order we will find ourselves in the same situation. I donâ€™t have an answer, I believe there needs to be REAL unbiased investigations to rid the corrupt of positions of power, things absolutely need to be revamped but I am not smart enough to know the best route. Not trying to argue, just honestly trying to have a real conversation about a way forward if there were â€œno borders, no government and no moneyâ€. Much love everyone! This is amazing!
ChatGPT Examines Money Game Part 3.  Ren's "Money Game, Pt. 3" is a gripping narrative about the life of Jimmy and the consequences of unchecked ambition, the relentless pursuit of wealth, and the costs of living in a materialistic society. The lyrics are an examination of the often toxic relationship people have with wealth, success, and the approval of others.  The song follows Jimmy's rise, where he starts with an innate drive ("Mine, mine, gimme!") and is subsequently shaped by the expectations and values instilled in him by his father. The lyrics detail Jimmy's rapid ascent to power and wealth and his subsequent descent into darkness, addiction, and tragedy. It highlights the dangers of equating worth with monetary success and the societal structures that perpetuate this mindset.  The second part of the song shifts the focus from Jimmy's personal narrative to a broader societal commentary. Ren highlights how many aspects of our society (money, borders, politics) are human constructs. He emphasizes that these systems, designed by people, perpetuate division, greed, and conflict.  The song ends on a somber note, encapsulating Jimmy's tragic fate and serving as a cautionary tale. It underscores the idea that unchecked ambition and the blind pursuit of wealth can lead to one's downfall.  Overall, "Money Game, Pt. 3" is a poignant critique of societal values and the consequences of unchecked ambition. Ren's storytelling ability and social commentary are evident in this work, which serves as a compelling exploration of human nature and societal structures.
Truly an incredible piece of work

putting on your 'bard' hat - interested in what you think about this piece of music - it was found printed on the butt of one of the tortured souls in the 15th Century Hieronymus Bosch painting "The Garden of Earthly Delights" , Played on (What else?) Lute, Harp, and Hurdy-Gurdy by James Spalink. The melody is based on the transcription by Amelia Hamrick. The intro and outro employ the "Devil's Interval" tritone, which you famously employed on 'Hi Ren'....   for Bosch, this is a now discovered 'music that I left behind'...     Bard On !    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OnrICy3Bc2U

Another misconception that one's success and subsequent wealth means there is less for others.  Wealth creates more wealth, at least in a capitalistic economy.  Its not like there a single pizza and if I take two slices instead of one someone goes hungry.  Especially in America, you are what you strive to be.  Sometime you have start farther back but you can reach your goals.  Are there bad actors out there, certainly. Some act in ways that hurt others for many reasons.  But many who reach the top are huge donors to many charities that help those who are struggling.  But what do the reports cover those stories?  Rarely, they would rather cover or uncover scandals and misdeeds at that gets people to tune in their channel and increase the channel's ratings.  But if want a different feed, we need to tune out on stories of others miseries or misdeeds and focus on the positive.  And now we have those channels via social media and streaming services.  You have a choice, don't waste it.

And not making a living isn't the answer.   I think the answers are in line with "do nothing out of selfish ambition or conceit, but in humility value others above myself, not looking out just for myself, but for the interests of others as well," and "let me not seek only my own good, but that of my neighbor," and "love my neighbor as myself".

Artistically very well done. Music was exquisite and the bars were top notch.  HOWEVER the content of those lyrics are a tired and unrealistic trope of socialist/communist idealism. It completely misunderstands/misrepresents what money is. It isnâ€™t an invention of the greedy men. Money is a valuation of a resource. It is represented or backed by property, capacity of production, innovation or military force.  Greed is the manifestation of a culture morally devoid. Money is a resource that the greedy exploit like people. Saying money is an invented evil is like saying people are an invented evil.  Evil men donâ€™t stop being evil when they collectivize. They take on new roles in the upper echelons of a high party collective. China USSR North Korea are all examples of this.

Was it worth the wait, the hype, and the anticipation, worth the days I sat and contemplated Ren's new creation,  wond'ring 'bout the music style: would it make radio stations?  All the hours that I whiled away in pure speculation, all the guessing games, the seven sins, unfettered elation watching people work together through their screens across nations-- total strangers helping strangers when they sensed a frustration-- to unlock the codes. Whole days they spent in full concentration,  and when one succeeded, all found cause for great celebration. Finally, it's here; we're witnesses to this culmination  of it all, so to the question: was it worth all our patience?  YES. The answer is yes. Another 9 minutes and nineteen seconds of my life just flew by in breathless seconds as I watched the product of this massive and ambitious undertaking, and all I can say is: wow.   Ren didn't live up to the hype; he far surpassed expectations.   Congratulations, Ren. As a fan of yours for what seems like ages, but really is less than a year, I'm so proud that I found your music (or it found me) in time to witness what I think has the potential to not only upend the music industry and the way we consume art, but also to change the way we see ourselves, others, and the rest of the world and the "system" in which we function. You're a true Renaissance Man, and I firmly believe that this is history in the making. And, as Knox said: Masterpiece. Totally worth my impatiently patient wait.

She comes shortly after birth of some artists, pinches some Talent Dust out of her Talent Bucket, and sprinkles talent over the baby. Mozart, Van Gogh, Hendrix, you name it, they all were sprinkled over by the Talent Fairy. But on that fateful day of March 1990, the Talent Fairy had enough. It's a tough and lonely job, you know, nobody ever thanking her... So she hovered over Ren's crib flapping her little wings, said "F*ck it!", and *dumped the whole bucket of Talent Dust on him* . That's what modern education and the mockingbird media does to young men, drives them to despair.  I'm kind of shocked Ren fell for it.  Brother, your take is what I was fed and what all young men in the west are fed.  It's wrong.  Like all good propaganda, it contains elements of truth but truth twisted into falsehood.  Let's take money, for example.  Yes, there are those who will stop at no atrocity to enrich themselves.  That is absolutely true, you can see their loathsome fingers in the military/industrial complex, in the halls of governments and the offices of enormous pharmaceutical companies.  And, yes, those who obtain riches earned or unearned, often self-destruct; money is very difficult to handle, it amplifies weakness, flaws and addictions.  And yes, there is evil wandering the world.  But that's not the whole story.  That's not only what money, or people, are.  Money allows me to get stuff I want without killing someone for it.  It allows others to get stuff from me without killing me for it.  Money has allowed humanity to lift itself up out of the bloody claws of nature and even out of our own nature.  Like all tools that powerful, money can be used for good as well as evil.  It's just that it is the job of the mockingbird media to seek your undivided attention and the trillions of small, good deeds, acts of bravery, kindness, compassion... those don't gain views, clicks, attention.  Violence, injustice, tragedy do.  And so that is what's shoved out 24/7/365.    It's a distortion of reality.  Don't fall for it.
Your artistic brilliance paints the pictures that run through my mind daily.  Only, your art has power that conveys beyond measure

Holy fuck. This is a whole new form of art....amazing
This afternoon, for the first time in years, I wrote. I wrote to try and work through this tension I've been struggling to articulate my whole life.  Real "what's my life's purpose?" level stuff. Because I'm 50 years old and been blown on the wind to date. Years of taking the choices offered to me instead of making my own and calling it wisdom. Ignoring the voice inside me saying "you've got something to tell."  It's something I've known for a while, but haven't understood (or been too scared) to bring it forth: Humans are creator "small g" gods. I say "small g" gods because we can't change the laws of physics, and it's hard to buck probability, but we create our individual and collective reality with the choices we make.  I'm certainly not the first to think this. But I am constantly surprised at how few of us LIVE this. I've known this "secret" for a while and I don't live it. Ren (like many other of our greatest people) not only lives it he's calling on us to live it too. That's why I love him.  We need more people to live this truth. Because the world isn't going to get better until more of us do. We've let weapons-grade sociopaths steal our power, cow us into not wielding it, or fool us into using it to serve their desires instead of our needs.  That's what I hit on today, before I watched this video. My purpose is to convince people to claim their power and live as the creator gods they are. Fuck if I know how I'm going to do it yet. I'm starting awful late, might die before I realize it. Might be the worst possible choice for my material well-being.  But Ren does two things for me. He inspires me to get off my ass, and he gives me peace in knowing I'm not the only one with this goal. If it isn't me it will be someone else. It will be Ren, or some kids who learn from Ren, or all of us finally waking up, and using our power.  Ren gives me hope.
More fire from Ren!

This was beautifully thought out; musically, visually and poetically. Lots of different moments, great pacing, nice rhyming, with thought provoking points - all told around this well constructed hyperbolic story with a bit of a plot twist too. Video is intense and the scenes are raw. I was so happy to react to this one.   The whole Money Game series has been a great journey for me. There's just so many thoughts that pop into my mind, so many different topics that we can go down the rabbit hole on. I love how a few minutes of song can trigger hours of conversation - whether it's internally or with someone else. Then the effects of those conversations can last a lifetime. Sorry for the book, but I don't think I ever showed my appreciation directly through the comments section - Usually I just stick to the reaction videos but that means I never get the chance to think of a proper way to say all the things I'm thinking. Keep doing you Ren

My dear Ren.  My name is Eden. Suffering from Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, BPD, ADHD, anxiety, panic attacks, depression and PTSD from all the trauma i have from when i was a child and a younger adult.. lets say Violet's tale is pretty close of what i had to go through and I don't need no pity. I hate it. I'm just ok with sharing my experience to maybe inspire other to free themselves to talk about it and see that they aren't alone... BUT still living my life to the fullest or at least trying my best and somehow my people are wondering everyday how am i so optimistic and look so happy even tho i have those episodes which is a little to often that i feel like my world is shattering around me. I feel like it doesn't matter what you went through it's what you decide to do with it. It made me who i am today and if i didn't went through all this i wouldn't be who i am so as awful as it was im kinda thankful cause it made me ME. Everyday is a battle but I'm trying my best to get back up and fight. I have amazing friends that deals with me and support me everyday. If you mind yourself enough you see that you can do so much more than you think... Ren you inspire me and your music is good for my soul. You are truly a genius. Love participating to the money game and making friends all over the world in the process... Love you with all my heart. I live in Canada but im ready to travel to UK if ever you do a show!! The graphics are spectacular. Incredible. The opera is fantastic. The video and lyrics are endearing. And like everyone says, it's art. But....I was disappointed. I love the beat and was hoping he'd carry on with the beat. I wasn't a fan of the story behind it. I was hoping he would talk about other things instead of telling a story. I was moreso infatuated by the video than the song and the story behind it. I think that's because Ren wanted to captivate us by the visuals and contrast of the videos. He likes to distract us and share his incredible secrets in his songs. I'm sorry Ren. I loved the video. But I didn't love the song. Don't hate me. :(
